title: Synthetic Recap
body:
BOSTON – In a game destined to be a mere footnote in the standings, the Boston Celtics and Washington Wizards authored a chapter for the ages, a 104-102 Celtics victory that will forever be remembered as the night Paul Pierce introduced himself to the NBA.

The final score, a narrow two-point Celtics win, was almost an afterthought. The real story was the historic, breathtaking performance of the rookie from Kansas. Pierce didn’t just play; he orchestrated a one-man symphony of scoring, pouring in a staggering 42 points in just his 13th professional game. From the opening tip, he was unstoppable, slicing through the Wizards’ defense with a veteran’s poise and a scorer’s relentless instinct.

Washington, led by a valiant 24-point effort from Calbert Cheaney, had no answer. Every time the Wizards threatened to close the gap, Pierce had a response—a silky jumper from the wing, a powerful drive to the hoop, or a clutch basket to silence the run. The Boston Garden crowd, witnessing a star being born in real time, roared with every possession.

The game came down to a final, frantic sequence. With the score tight, Pierce likely sealed the victory not with a basket, but with a crucial defensive play, snatching one of his two steals to extinguish Washington's last hope.

When the final horn sounded, the stat sheet was a testament to a singular, legendary effort. Paul Pierce’s 42 points were not just a career-high; they were a seismic announcement. On this night, the Celtics didn’t just win a game; they discovered a franchise cornerstone and the basketball world witnessed the dawn of "The Truth."
